  1. Saturday, February 8th: Live Monday Musings writing session

  3. Wednesday, February 12th: Business writing workshop‚Äã
  4. Saturday, February 15th: Live discussion group for my new 16,000-word long-form essay, News in the Age of Abundance.

While we're talking about the essay, I created a 35-minute video that outlines my process for collecting notes, outlining my ideas, organizing them, and editing my work. It's unlike anything I've ever created, and you can watch it here. It's the single best window into my long-form writing process.

Oh... and.... I'm also launching a surprise writing-related project next week that nobody knows about... üòú

‚Äã

Friday Finds

Here are today's links:

Singapore: A series of four outstanding Reddit posts, which summarized Lee Kuan Yew's book, From Third World to First. The posts will take you a few hours to read, but you'll leave with a deep understanding of how the country operates. If these ideas interest you, you'll also enjoy my essay on the history of Singapore.

‚ÄãHow Airplanes Fly: The physics of flight has interested me ever since I was a kid. I took flying lessons during high school, in part because of a program for Bay Area teenagers called Young Eagles, which allowed kids like myself to fly airplanes for free. Yes, it was as cool as it sounds. To this day, I still turn my head whenever a plane flies above me. My past three apartments have been under the LaGuardia Airport flight path because I love watching jets land and twist and turn and glide like hawks on a windy afternoon. This article explains the science of aerodynamics as well as anything I've ever seen.

‚ÄãWhere Greatness Comes From: I keep coming back to this short movie clip from Whiplash. In it, a drummer breaks up with his girlfriend because he wants to focus on his craft. I won't tell you any more because I don't want to spoil it. Apparently, Whiplash was one of Kobe Bryant's favorite movies, and after you watch this short clip, you'll understand why. Pair it with this interview with Kobe Bryant and a short article called Whiplash and Extreme Greatness.

‚ÄãMimetic Theory: This is an unbelievable explanation of Mimetic Theory, and it's probably the best one I've ever seen. The theory was developed by Rene Girard, a cultural anthropologist who history will remember as one of the greatest scholars of all-time. If you're looking for a video summary, I recommend this series of five interviews with Girard himself. Peter Thiel and Girard were close friends. Thiel spoke at Girard's funeral, and I wrote extensively about the influence of Mimetic Theory on Thiel's worldview in this essay.

Until next week,

David Perell

Hi friends,

Today is a big day.

I‚Äôm thrilled to announce my newest long-form essay, News in the Age of Abundance.‚Äã

I‚Äôve been officially working on the essay since August, but I‚Äôve been collecting notes for it for the past few years. It‚Äôs a sequel to What the Hell is Going On, which explores the transition from information scarcity to information abundance. Both essays are born out of a deep frustration with people‚Äôs relationship to the information environment.

We have infinite access to high-quality information, but spend most of our time reading low-quality news; we have infinite access to the wisdom of history, but we spend more of our time consuming information made in the past 24 hours. Infinite access to information will either cripple you or strengthen you ‚Äî which is the essence of all my work, from writing this newsletter, to recording my podcasts, to teaching Write of Passage.

In the past decade, nothing in the world has changed more than our information environment. We‚Äôre surrounded by infinite access to facts, ideas, and breaking news stories. If we follow the gravity of our social media feeds, we‚Äôll destroy ourselves. But if we can become intelligent news consumers, we‚Äôll create the heaven our ancestors dreamed about.

This new essay is 16,000-words. That‚Äôs how long I needed to give you the tools, the frameworks, and the language to understand our information environment.

‚ÄãYou can read the essay here.‚Äã

And now‚Ä¶ for the fun part. On February 15th, I‚Äôll be hosting a Monday Musings essay club where we can all meet each other and talk about the news together. You‚Äôll have time to ask me questions and connect with other hyper-curious Musings readers.

‚ÄãSign up here if you want to chat about News in the Age of Abundance.

‚Äã

----------

‚Äã

Write of Passage Writing Week

‚Äã

In other news, to celebrate the next cohort of Write of Passage which begins on February 19th, I‚Äôll be hosting four live writing events in the next two weeks.

Here‚Äôs the schedule:

‚ÄãFebruary 8th: Live Monday Musings Writing Session. I‚Äôll give you a behind-the-scenes look at how I write this newsletter every week.

‚ÄãFebruary 11th: Interview with Alex Danco, one of my all-time favorite writers. I first started reading Alex‚Äôs writing in college, and his work inspired me to write essays like the one I published today. Alex has more original ideas than any other online writer I follow, and in this interview, he‚Äôll share his system for writing and coming up with counter-intuitive ideas.

‚ÄãFebruary 12th: POP Writing Workshop. My writing coach Ellen Fishbein and I developed our own framework for business writing, and now it‚Äôs time to share it. It‚Äôs called POP Writing, and it‚Äôll give you a systematic way to improve the clarity and energy of your writing.

‚ÄãFebruary 13: Interview with Nathan Barry, the founder of ConvertKit and the author of Authority. We‚Äôll be discussing my Audience-First Products thesis and the benefits of writing online.

If you‚Äôd like to join, you can follow the links above. Or, you can sign up here and I‚Äôll send you details about them.

‚Äã

‚Äã

‚Äã

Coolest Things I Learned This Week

Asking Questions: What a Beautiful Quote

This quote from David Whyte explains why intellectual curiosity is such a wonderful virtue.

‚Ä™‚ÄúThe ability to ask beautiful questions, often in very unbeautiful moments, is one of the great disciplines of a human life. And a beautiful question starts to shape your identity as much by asking it, as it does by having it answered. You just have to keep asking. And before you know it, you will find yourself actually shaping a different life, meeting different people, finding conversations that are leading you in those directions that you wouldn‚Äôt even have seen before.‚Äù

‚Äã

----------

‚Äã

Looking for Paradoxes

I saw Peter Thiel speak in New York last week, and realized that one of Thiel‚Äôs core strengths is the ability to find truth inside of paradox. Too often, we conflate truth with binary logic. But many of the deepest truths are deeply counterintuitive. Paradoxes are an access code to a new kingdom of ideas.

The best example of this comes in Chapter 14 of Thiel‚Äôs book, Zero to One. Naturally, it‚Äôs called ‚ÄúThe Founder‚Äôs Paradox.‚Äù

The rest of this section is directly from Thiel's book:

Some people are strong, some are weak, some are geniuses, some are dullards‚Äîbut most people are in the middle. Plot where everyone falls and you‚Äôll see a bell curve:

‚Äã

Since so many founders seem to have extreme traits, you might guess that a plot showing only founders‚Äô traits would have fatter tails with more people at either end.

‚Äã

But that doesn‚Äôt capture the strangest thing about founders. Normally we expect opposite traits to be mutually exclusive: a normal person can‚Äôt be both rich and poor at the same time, for instance. But it happens all the time to founders: startup CEOs can be cash poor but millionaires on paper. They may oscillate between sullen jerkiness and appealing charisma. Almost all successful entrepreneurs are simultaneously insiders and outsiders. And when they do succeed, they attract both fame and infamy. When you plot them out, founders‚Äô traits appear to follow an inverse normal distribution:

‚Äã

‚Äã

----------

‚Äã

Dietary Guidelines

Well‚Ä¶ this is scary.

71.6 of Americans are now overweight, and the rise of obesity lines up with the launch of American dietary guidelines in 1980.

Correlation does not equal causation, but this is worth investigating.

‚Äã

‚Äã

----------

‚Äã

‚ÄãJosh Wolfe‚Äôs Favorite Investor Quotes‚Äã

1. F. Scott Fitzgerald: ‚ÄúThe test of a first-rate intelligence is the ability to hold two opposed ideas in mind at the same time and still retain the ability to function.‚Äù

To be a good investor, you have to keep multiple future scenarios of the future in your head. For example, if you‚Äôre thinking about China, you have to think that the economy could collapse or that it will become the engine of the global economy.

2. Schopenhauer: "Talent hits a target no one else can hit. Genius hits a target no one else can see."

Peter Thiel talks about the importance of finding secrets in Zero to One. When you find somebody who knows something important about the world that other people don‚Äôt, consider betting on them. Likewise, Wolfe looks for the ‚ÄúValley of Mismatch.‚Äù He looks for times when the way we do things has been lagging the pace of technological improvements for a long time. For example, Figma started replacing Photoshop recently even though the demand for collaborative design has existed for decades.

3. Twain: "What gets us into trouble is not what we don't know. It's what we know for sure that just ain't so."

The lesson: The worst problems aren‚Äôt the ones we were worried about. They are the surprises we didn‚Äôt even think about.

Wolfe‚Äôs third lesson reminds me of Cliff Assnes‚Äô explanation of the Financial Crisis in an interview with Tyler Cowen: ‚ÄúAny form of near certainty without certainty ‚Äî any time you convince the world that something is a certainty but it‚Äôs not, it‚Äôs the most dangerous time humanly possible‚Ä¶ You know what did it, if I had to pick one thing, that one primary cause of the financial crisis? The assumption that real estate prices can‚Äôt go down. The government made this assumption, the people who say these terrible quantitative models were way off. At the end of the day, somewhere in this giant model, in a thousand lines of computer code, there was, 'What‚Äôs the worst case 10‚Äëyear return for real estate?' If that worse case was not losing money, it‚Äôs garbage in, garbage out. You can have the best model in the world. That‚Äôs a problem."

‚Äã

----------

‚Äã

Sunlight in Europe and America

My friend Nick Maggiulli, an outstanding writer shared this graph in his newsletter.

‚Äã

‚Äã

‚Äã

‚Äã

Photo of the Week

‚Äã

On Saturday, I visited the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum with Sid Jha.

We sat at the helm of the 873 foot, 24,580 ton Intrepid aircraft carrier. America used it during World War II, where it survived five kamikaze attacks and one torpedo strike. Then, we touched the Enterprise Space Shuttle, which was build for NASA to perform atmospheric test flights after being launched from a modified Boeing 747.

Sid is one of my favorite up-and-coming writers. He‚Äôs working on a book about Lyndon B. Johnson, which will explore how LBJ used the principles that govern networks, organizations, and people to go from being born to the poorest family in Texas Hill Country to the President of the United States.

‚ÄãSign up here to receive a PDF of the book when it comes out.

Until next week,

David Perell

2. On Monday, I published an essay called "The Social Media Trap." People change their behavior when they know they're being watched. 24/7 access to social media has over-socialized us, and we now lack the courage to take risks and the audacity to dream big. You can read the entire post here.‚Äã

Friday Finds

‚ÄãShock of the New: I watch lots of YouTube videos, but usually they're shorter than this series. For the past few weeks, I've been watching this excellent 8-part documentary on art history, hosted by Robert Hughes. The series traces the 100-year history of modern art, from the Impressionists in 1880 to the postmodernists in 1980. And if you like the documentary, I recommend the book with the same title.‚Äã

‚ÄãSpace in High Definition: An ultra-high quality photo of the stars and the sky. Open it on a computer browser, zoom in as much as you can, and open your heart to the vastness of the universe.

Edge: This website is a hidden treasure. On it, you'll find all kinds of interviews with great writers and articles about forgotten scientific ideas. I don't know how this website has managed to fly under the radar for so long, but it's worthy of your attention. Start with this essay on Composers as Gardners, this one on the problems with String Theory, or this interview with Rory Sutherland.

‚ÄãBowling Alone: Robert Putnam's book Bowling Alone is one of the most influential pieces of American sociology ever written. In it, he talks about the decline of social life in America, including the fall in church membership, attendance at public meetings, and the number of Americans who participate in associations. This is an excellent summary of the book.

item.content:encoded:
‚Äã

Hey everybody,

Greetings from New York!

The next two Mondays are going to be exciting. On February 3rd, I'll publish a 15,000-word essay on the news. Then, the upcoming Write of Passage cohort opens for sale on February 10th before it begins on February 19th.

First, some background on the news essay. I've been working on it since August! I plan to review final edits this week, so I can publish it on Monday. In it, you'll learn about the history of newspapers, television, and how the Internet transformed the news industry. I'll also introduce you to terms like Russell Conjugations, Common Knowledge, and Gresham's Law, and show you how they shape our media environment.

In other writing news, all my Write of Passage Fellows just published a 1,500-word article. Think of these articles as compressed versions of the longer 10,000-word essays they'll be publishing in April.

I'd appreciate your involvement. The fellows are looking for your help with edits, feedback, and introductions to experts in their field of study. If you'd like to get involved, you can reach out to each of the fellows on Twitter or respond to this email with a note I can forward to the writer of your choice.

‚ÄãYou can read all the articles here.‚Äã

Essay topics include:

  • ‚ÄãJessy Lin: Human-centered artificial intelligence‚Äã
  • ‚ÄãMason Hartman: Transforming childhood education‚Äã
  • ‚ÄãTamara Winter: Life, death and future of new cities‚Äã
  • ‚ÄãJoe Wells: Compulsory national service‚Äã
  • ‚ÄãOshan Jarow: Universal basic income‚Äã
  • ‚ÄãPacky McCormick: Building Communities of Genius‚Äã
  • ‚ÄãSuthen Siva: Re-Engineering Magic in Cities‚Äã
  • ‚ÄãRhys Lindmark: Catalyzing a post-capitalist paradigm‚Äã
  • ‚ÄãAdrienne Tran: Consumer choice in an age of abundance‚Äã
  • ‚ÄãAsh Fontana: How to compete with artificial intelligence‚Äã

‚Äã

The Social Media Trap

‚ÄãThis article was originally posted on my website.‚Äã

People change their behavior when they know they're being watched. And on social media, somebody can always look at you.

We used to hand-write personal thoughts in our diaries. Even when we dropped our pens and spoke out loud, our thoughts never reached an audience bigger than the friends in our kitchen at Thanksgiving dinner. Even our peers who wanted to keep tabs on us weren‚Äôt able to track our every career decision like they can today.

‚ÄãEugene Wei, the former director of video for Oculus VR at Facebook, says that posting on social media makes people feel like a public company.

"Most celebrities learn this lesson very early on, most companies put their public-facing executives through PR training, but most humans never grew up under the watchful gaze of hundreds of millions of eyes of Sauron‚Ä¶Public companies are restricted in what they can say publicly. The same is true for people who take themselves public. The markets punish companies that stumble, and the judgment of the masses is no less harsh for individuals who do their thinking out loud on social media."

Building personal brands has turned us all into public relations professionals. Public companies are notoriously risk-averse. Compared to private ones, they operate on short-term horizons and face more scrutiny when they make bold bets. In practice, we now have to justify risky career moves to our friends, so it‚Äôs often easier to follow the well-worn path, do what everybody else is doing, and guarantee the approval of our peers.

Public companies and people on social media are always being watched. For public companies, the evaluation happens in the real-time movement of the stock market ticker. Meanwhile, people on social media are judged in likes, comments, and social status. Like the stock market, your social status fluctuates every time you post online. Post a photo of your six-pack abs on the beach in Tulum and your status will rise. Tell your friends that you‚Äôre leaving Goldman Sachs to join a growing and profitable company in rural Wyoming, and the backroom gossip will begin.

As Jia Tolentino writes in Trick Mirror:

"Where we had once been free to be ourselves online, we were now chained to ourselves online, and this made us self-conscious."

24/7 access to social media has over-socialized us. Every action is criticized, every sentence is scrutinized, until soon, we get stuck in a prison of fear and risk-aversion. Plus, the Internet has a perfect memory. It only takes one tweet to end your career and permanently tarnish your Google search results. Like public relations professionals, we've become hyper-aware of how the masses will respond to everything we say and do.

By creating an audience of critics, all those eyes have changed how we act. Psychologists call this the Hawthorne Effect, and it states that people change their behavior when they know they‚Äôre being watched. It was originally discovered in 1958 when researchers tried to study the effect of bright lighting on working hours and break times. Once the study began, worker productivity improved, but it slumped again after it ended. Researchers concluded that people worked harder not because of changing light conditions in the factory, but because they were being watched.

Thus, surveillance is a tradeoff. Under the critical eye of the social media panopticon, people are more likely to follow the rules but also take fewer risks ‚Äî which creates a stagnant society.

On social media, we create our own Big Brother. The laid-back honesty users once had when posting on Instagram and Twitter in the platforms‚Äô early days is gone now. Spend enough time on both platforms, and you‚Äôll begin to operate with the tact of a corporate communications professional. Both platforms are performative. On Instagram, we judge every post by its impact on our public image, and on Twitter, we have to examine how our ideas will be interpreted by a wide range of audiences ‚Äî today and in the future ‚Äî with permanent records of everything we publish. Now that our failures are on public display, we've stopped taking risks.

In 1984, George Orwell wrote: ‚ÄúThe party told you to reject the evidence of your eyes and ears. It was their final, most essential command.‚Äù Stuck behind the bars of the Social Media Trap, streams of censorship turn into mental blood clots which prevent the flow of ideas. When we create for an audience of many, we censor ourselves and stop taking risks because we watch ourselves being watched.

Social media has turned us into objects of criticism. Instead of looking at the world, we watch ourselves being looked at. Like celebrities stuck in the prison of fame, instead of controlling our audience, our audience starts controlling us. Crippled by the thought of friends and family criticizing us behind our backs, we stop taking risks and collapse under the weight of paralysis.

The problem is worse on social media platforms where we surround ourselves with people from our past. More practically, people would work on riskier but more ambitious projects if they left Instagram. Trapped by the judgment of our peers, we stop taking risks or trusting ourselves. Over time, the shouts of intuition turn into whispers, and soon, quiet. The self is silenced, the crowd screams, and yet, we hold our ear to the cacophony of judgmental noise.

‚Äî ‚Äî

Seeking Solitude

"Every prophet has to come from civilization, but every prophet has to go into the wilderness. He must have a strong impression of a complex society and all that it has to give, and then he must serve periods of isolation and meditation. This is the process by which psychic dynamite is made.‚Äù ‚Äî Winston Churchill

We‚Äôve never had better access to technology, but we use social media to cripple ourselves. In a time when the world is starving for action-oriented risk-takers, we‚Äôve stopped taking risks for fear of social rejection. Study the past, and you‚Äôll see that many of the best opportunities are hidden in plain sight. At every point in human history, our ancestors have been deluded by grand fallacies and blind to grand opportunities. Find what we‚Äôre wrong about today. Then bet on your answers. Escape the Social Media Trap, and you‚Äôll find the audacity to silence the critics and march with conviction.

But in an age where millions of people are stuck in the Social Media Trap, how can we summon the courage to take a leap of faith?

Spend more time alone. Our values are formed when we are by ourselves, so it‚Äôs hard to have original ideas the judgment of other people is always ringing in your mind. Too many schools teach students what to think, not how to think.

If you insist on using social media, use it to motivate yourself, raise your ambitions, and hold yourself accountable. Curate your feeds, so you can surround yourself with people who inspire you.

Social environments reward conformity, but the world needs people with visions of a better future for society and themselves. It needs people who can shatter the chains of short-term judgment of the Social Media Trap. It needs time-travelers who can escape the solipsism of the present, apply the wisdom of history, and challenge the heresies of the present day. It needs people who can inject moral courage into their veins, follow their intuitive compass, and march along a foggy road towards a flourishing future.

‚Äã

Coolest Things I Learned This Week

‚ÄãMy Favorite Kobe Bryant Story‚Äã

I've never been hit as hard by a celebrity death as I was by the tragic news of Kobe Bryant.

In his memory, I collected all my favorite Kobe stories, ideas, and videos in a thread on Twitter.

Forgive the long excerpt, but this is my favorite story about the "Black Mamba." May we carry the torch of his hustle, passion, and incredible work ethic.

‚ÄãHere we go:‚Äã

"The player who stood out amongst the stars was Kobe Bryant.

Rob had worked with some of the other members of the USA basketball team before, but this would be his first interaction with Kobe. It was so powerful, that he shared it with the world on Reddit so everyone could get a glimpse into Kobe Bryant's insane work ethic.

Here is his story:

In his first meeting with Kobe, Rob talked about what he specialized in, where Kobe would like to be by the end of summer, and about the hustle of his teammates. Rob then gave Kobe his number and told him to call him any time he wanted to do some extra conditioning work.

Two days later, Kobe woke up Rob with a call at 4:15am in the morning.

"Hey, uhh Rob, I hope I'm not disturbing anything right?"

"Uhh no, what's up Kobe?"

"Just wondering if you could just help me out with some conditioning work, that's all."

"Yeah sure, I'll see you in the facility in a bit."

20 minutes later, Rob arrived at the training facility. There he saw Kobe‚Äìalone and drenched in so much sweat it looked like he'd just come from a pool. It was not even 5am yet!

The two of them worked on conditioning for about 75 minutes, then did about 45 minutes of weight training. Then at 7am, Rob went back to his hotel to get some quick rest before the day‚Äôs practice. Meanwhile, Kobe went back to the gym to practice his shooting.

Rob was expected back at 11am. So he slept a couple of hours, got a quick breakfast, and then headed back to the gym exhausted and sleep deprived.

When he arrived, he saw all of the members of Team USA there. Lebron was talking to Carmelo, Coach Krzyzewski was explaining something to Kevin Durant and, on the right side of the facility all by himself, Kobe was shooting jumpers.

Rob went up to Kobe and said, ‚ÄúGood work this morning.‚Äù

‚ÄúHuh?‚Äù

"Like, the conditioning. Good work."

"Oh. Yeah, thanks Rob. I really appreciate it."

"So when did you finish?"

"Finish what?"

"Getting your shots up. What time did you leave the facility?"

"Oh just now. I wanted 800 makes...so yeah, just now."

Rob‚Äôs jaw dropped.

Kobe was drenched in sweat before 5am, worked with Rob on strength and conditioning for 2 hours, then made 800 shots between the hours of 7am and 11am.

And this all took place before practice!

At 34 years of age, with 5 NBA championships, 2 NBA Finals Most Valuable Player awards, 2 scoring titles, and soon to be 2 Olympic Gold Medals, Kobe was still waking up before 4am and working out for at least 7 hours before practice even began!"

‚Äã

How Kobe Bryant Used to Read

‚Äã

‚Äã

One Big Idea

I'm amazed by how many ultra-successful people find one big idea, and double-down on it. In the words of Adam Robinson, they build a hammer and look for nails.

Some examples:

  • ‚ÄãGeorge Soros: Reflexivity, inspired by Karl Popper
  • ‚ÄãPeter Thiel: Mimetic Theory, inspired by Rene Girard
  • Picasso: Cubism
  • ‚ÄãNassim Taleb: Risk in a world of "fat tails"
  • Charles Koch: The wisdom of free markets and entrepreneurship

As my writing coach Ellen mentioned, some people also find books that inform everything they do. She calls this "Finding Your Bible."

Three examples:

  1. Steve Jobs: Autobiography of a Yogi
  2. Bob Dylan: On the Road
  3. Shakespeare: Ovid's Metamorphoses

There's more complexity here that I need to sort through, so I'll be publishing an article on this idea in the next few weeks.

Oh, and here's how I think about my big idea: The Internet isn't just a new technology. It's a radical shift in human consciousness, as pervasive as clocks and electricity. Thus, the Internet is a way of being. I want to teach people how to become citizens of the Internet. I started with writing, but that's just a means to an end. I want to build upon Write of Passage by helping people build profitable online businesses, think with computers, and use the Internet to spark incredible friendships.

Costs of Starting a Franchise

‚Äã

Hey everybody,

Greetings from New York City!

I just finished the fourth full draft of my upcoming 20,000-word essay about the news. It's a sequel to What the Hell is Going On, and I can't wait to share it with you. I hope to publish it within the next three weeks.

I have two podcasts to share with you this week. The first is a podcast with Anthony Pompliano, who interviewed me about the history of journalism, cities as an engine for economic growth, and the future of online education (listen on Spotify or iTunes).

The second is a podcast with Robert Cottrell, the founder of The Browser. I interviewed him about business models for media and the cutting-edge of machine translation software (listen on Spotify or iTunes).

And finally, I have a paid job opporunity to announce. We're looking for editors to help with the Write of Passage Fellowship. We have ten people in the fellowship, all of whom are writing a 10,000 word essay on a topic of their choice. You'll find all the job details here.‚Äã

And now, let's talk about the rise of Audience-First Products.

‚Äã

‚Äã

‚ÄãAudience-First Products‚Äã

Note: You can also read this article on my website.‚Äã

I was a senior in college, and it was time to look for a job. So, I went to my school‚Äôs job fair.

From the second I arrived, I knew the job fair was a dead end. Hundreds of job-hunting students were walking around with the same blue suits, the same black portfolios, the same red pens, and the same lost expressions. The recruiters were advertising the kinds of jobs that knock the soul out of people‚Äîthe kinds of jobs that inhale our young, talented people and turn them into cogs.

The numbers tell the story. According to a 2013 Harvard Business Review survey of 12,000 professionals, half of the respondents said their job had no meaning and significance.

A job at most of these corporations was a short term win, but a long-term loss.

I wanted something different for myself.

------------

My First Job

The Internet is a better matching tool than a job fair will ever be. Even in college, back when I had less than 1,000 followers on Twitter, I could reach the kinds of decisionmakers I would have never met at a job fair. After I left the job fair, I committed to using Twitter to find a job. The next week I woke up late on a Tuesday morning where the rain was coming down sideways. I didn‚Äôt feel like going outside, so I skipped class to write a series of tweets about the future of online publishing. With them, I attracted the attention of the CEO of Laundry Service, a New York-based advertising agency I wanted to work for. Impressed by my ideas, he replied with eight words that changed my life: ‚ÄúInterested in working with us when you graduate?‚Äù

‚Äã

Ever since Jason‚Äôs unexpected message, I‚Äôve used the Internet to create every meaningful professional opportunity, including my first business.

The Internet swallows up an increasing percentage of our leisure time, but people under-estimate the economic opportunities it presents ‚Äî even for college seniors. First, I discovered a better way to find a job. Then, I used the Internet to build my business. What follows is the three-step process I‚Äôve used to create professional opportunities online.

------------

The Rise of Audience-First Products

My method of ‚ÄúAudience-First Products‚Äù is still experimental, but I believe it‚Äôs repeatable. It‚Äôs a new way to test the feasibility of a business idea. It stands in stark contrast to the ‚Äúold guard‚Äù model of attending job fairs, working mindless jobs to learn professional skills, and raising money before you start a business. Just like the job fair, there is a better way to start a business.

Here‚Äôs the three-step process I used to capitalize on the transition to the online economy:

(1) build an audience

(2) build a product

(3) scale the solution

Here‚Äôs how it works.

Step 1: Build an Audience: Before the Internet, companies built products before audiences. Now, they build audiences before products. Having an audience will give you a unique perspective on the world. You‚Äôll receive instant, high-quality feedback on the ideas you share. People are taught to hunt down interesting people, ideas, and opportunities. But masters of the Internet attract them. Sharing ideas attracts like-minded people, who double as a feedback loop to make you smarter and more interesting.

As you build your Audience-First Product, focus on resonance instead of scale. Most online metrics focus on how many people you reach, not the depth of relationships you build with them.

Ignore them, and make the Internet small instead. Define your interests. Then write about them. When you find a group that resonates with your writing, write more for them, if they‚Äôre the kind of people you want to connect with. As you do, you‚Äôll make it easy for other obsessives to find you. When you write in-depth about an off-the-beaten-path subject, you‚Äôll attract people at the outer edges of the personality curve. Use it to shrink the world, and surround yourself with like-minded people.

Define your own intersection of ideas by writing about topics nobody else is writing about, and putting a name to your perspective. When you write about a specific topic, you‚Äôll find common challenges which double as areas of entrepreneurial opportunity. As you do, you will define your unique lens on the world, share it passionately, and attract both casual friends and professional collaborators.

Step 2: Build a Product: Once you‚Äôve built an audience, you can focus on the second step of delivering a product to them. There are problems everywhere. Nearly every service could be delivered with more joy, in a more efficient manner. Study any industry for long enough and you‚Äôll find ways to improve it.

To build a product, you should solve a problem for your audience or yourself ‚Äî ideally both.

To build for your audience, ask: ‚ÄúWhat product does my audience need to solve a problem they have?‚Äù

And to build for yourself, ask: ‚ÄúWhat product can I build to make my life easier?"

Regardless, the bigger the overlap between the audience you attract and the product you sell, the more successful you‚Äôll be. For example, Nathan Barry built an email service provider called ConvertKit after building his online audience of people who wanted to learn about web design and building authority online. ConvertKit has always been designed for his creative process, so Barry‚Äôs always had an intuitive sense of how to build the product.

If people are continuously annoyed about something, there‚Äôs an opportunity to build a product. If an obvious customer pain point hasn‚Äôt been solved, there‚Äôs probably a reason why. But you‚Äôll find economic opportunities in common problems people don‚Äôt know they have.

‚ÄãPeter Thiel famously asks: ‚ÄúWhat very important truth do very few people agree with you on?‚Äù

My answer is that writing online is massively underrated. It‚Äôs one of the world‚Äôs biggest arbitrage opportunities. Blogs have global reach, and the demand for quality ideas far exceeds the supply of them. But content creation is hard. Without structure or accountability, many people won‚Äôt be able to publish consistently. Until I started Write of Passage, nobody had claimed the niche for helping people write to accelerate their career. There were no methods, no frameworks, and no groups to support up-and-coming writers.

‚ÄãWrite of Passage is the online course I wish existed when I started writing. The system would have saved me hundreds of hours in setting up a website, building a note-taking system, and refining ideas before I published them. I had experienced the benefits and challenges of writing online myself, so I didn‚Äôt have to do market research. I launched the course with a built-in audience of 10,000 email subscribers and 20,000 Twitter followers. Since I had organic reach, I didn‚Äôt have to pay for marketing.

If you have a built-in audience, you don‚Äôt need to raise money. If you write well about a common and specific problem, Google will send you lots of free traffic. Looking back, I could have de-risked the online course by commanding an early-bird fee to cover my expenses while creating the course. I thought I needed to raise money to start a successful business, because venture capitalists are too good at marketing for society‚Äôs benefit. I had spent too much time studying the loud tactics of venture-scale companies and not enough time studying the quiet successes of bootstrapped companies.

Step 3: Scale with Software and Contractors

If you define your processes, you don‚Äôt have to hire full-time employees. Depending on their complexity, you can outsource repeatable processes to personal assistants and software programs.

The robots are already here. But they‚Äôre packed in Northern Virginia data centers, and don‚Äôt look like the human-style robots we saw in iRobot. Automate processes with code whenever possible. If you know how to code, you can build your own software. If you don‚Äôt, you can automate repeatable processes with tools like Zapier. But beware of chasing automation too fast. Don‚Äôt lose the human touch where it matters. Don‚Äôt forget the feeling of receiving a survey about a flight you missed; don‚Äôt forget the feeling of receiving email with the wrong person‚Äôs name on it; and don‚Äôt forget the feeling of receiving an automated text message from a gym you no longer go to.

Once a process has been automated, it‚Äôs hard to fight back against that inertia. In particular, make sure your systems are mature before you automate customer support and communications.

‚ÄãAndy McCune is one of the most talented entrepreneurs I know. He spent his teenage years buying and growing social media handles. His most successful one, Earth, has more than 1.3 million Instagram followers. At 23 years old, Andy just sold his company Unfold to Squarespace. His company was founded in 2018, and by the time it was acquired, Unfold users had used the app to create more than 700 million Instagram stories. The app had more than 20 million users, a couple million of which paid for the monthly subscription of $2.99/month. Best of all, Andy scaled the company with contractors instead of hiring full-time employees. At the time of acquisition, only three people worked full-time for Unfold. Together, those employees owned 100% of the business.

If you can‚Äôt automate a process with software, you can delegate it with contractors and personal assistants. They prefer well-defined projects and enjoy the repetitive tasks that drain the energy of an entrepreneur‚Äôs soul. As you work with them, ask them to refine and add detail to every process. The more granular the checklist, the better. That way, the process can be executed by any personal assistant, and eventually, by software.

This three-step process removes some of the risks of entrepreneurship without reducing the benefits to society.

------------

Why now?

We‚Äôve reached a tipping point for the creation of online businesses. First, it‚Äôs easier than ever to build an online audience. Future customers can find you on social media, stay connected with you through email, and build a relationship with you through articles and podcasts. Second, the number of no-code, plug-and-play software tools has exploded in the past five years. They‚Äôre almost all cheap to use at first, and the costs only rise as your business grows.

When I launched Write of Passage, there was no other school at the intersection of organizing your ideas, becoming a prolific writer, and working with a community to build an online audience. I launched Write of Passage with a built-in audience and without a lot of competition, so for the first year, I didn‚Äôt have to pay for marketing. I didn‚Äôt just have 10,000 email subscribers when I started selling the product. I had a trusted relationship with 10,000 people, many of whom saw me as an expert on writing online. Like a dam holding back water, there was a torrent of people who wanted to learn from me. Officially, there are only two people who work full-time on Write of Passage. But in another way, there are hundreds of people who do. The software tools I use are improving their products at a compounding rate, which gives me low-cost access to a ‚Äúshadow work force,‚Äù and keeps my company small so we can move fast. Thus, there are actually thousands of people working full-time to improve Write of Passage.

Avoiding competition is the best way to build an Audience-First Product. You must solve problems other people aren‚Äôt trying to solve. Do something unique. Don‚Äôt be the 800th person to sell T-shirts on Instagram. When in doubt, don‚Äôt differentiate on branding or packaging either. The world doesn‚Äôt need another copycat product, and your compensation will reflect that.

For years, we‚Äôve been taught to make the Internet big. Go global. Scale-up your efforts. Create products for billions of people. More, more, more.

But there are other paths to success too. Use the Audience-First Product method to make the Internet small. By writing online, you‚Äôll build a network around yourself and have a window into the ideas that ignite your soul. When you write online, you become a magnet that attracts like-minded people. Those people will share their best ideas, become your first customers, and help you grow your company.

‚Äã

‚Äã

‚Äã

Coolest Things I Learned This Week

Traveling Through Space

The first part of the space journey is the most fuel-intensive. From the NASA website:

"Travelling from the surface of Earth to Earth orbit is one of the most energy intensive steps of going anywhere else. This first step, about 400 kilometers away from Earth, requires half of the total energy needed to go to the surface of Mars.‚Äù

‚Äã

------------

‚Äã

The Coachella Music Setlist

Music labels have done an impressive job maintaining their control over the music industry compared to incumbents in other sectors of media.

In this graphic, somebody found the 2020 Coachella line-up and replaced the artist names with the music labels who represent them. WME, Paradigm, and CAA run the show.

‚Äã

‚Äã

‚Äã

------------

‚Äã

Different Kinds of Coffee

Jeremiah Lowin, an investor in Compass Coffee, dropped a fascinating knowledge bomb:

‚ÄúDark and light beans have almost the same amount of caffeine, but dark beans have more volume and less mass. Therefore if you measure by scoop, you get more caffeine from light beans. But if you measure by weight, dark wins.‚Äù

That‚Äôs why both of the bags in the following photo have five pounds of coffee, even though they are different sizes.

‚Äã

------------

‚Äã

Happiness: Smile Curve

Most people‚Äôs happiness levels change throughout their lives. It follows a U-Shape. Just remember, it looks like a smile. Derek Thompson (who is my favorite journalist these days) added two observations:

1. Happiness bounces back fast in our 60s‚Äîfaster than it declines in any other decade.

2. Happiness in life is U-shaped, declining until our early 50s and then coming back.

‚Äã

‚Äã

Photo of the Week

I spent Thursday afternooon recording a podcast for Anthony Pompliano's Off the Chain Podcast. He's one of the bigger names in the cryptocurrency sphere, so naturally, the podcast had a futuristic bent.

But this interview is loaded with ideas I've never spoken about before. The most interesting part of the podcast came when we discussed the urban real estate market. In cities like San Francisco, the middle class is leaving because most new San Francisco housing is built for people with "above moderate" incomes.

‚ÄãAs I've written before, where there are housing subsidies, they're geared towards low-income residents. Thus, there's hardly any new housing for people with moderate incomes, leading to the hallowing out of San Francisco's middle class. Where below market homes are built, the competition is brutal. 2,800 people applied for 60 units at one affordable housing development in SOMA. All this goes back to a single theme, summarized in The Economist last week: bad housing policy is ‚Äúthe West‚Äôs biggest economic policy mistake."

You can listen to the podcast on iTunes, Spotify, or the podcast app of your choice.

Until next week,

David Perell

item.content:encoded:
‚Äã

Hi friends,

Greetings from New York City.

The Write of Passage Fellowship officially begins this week. I'll be leading a team of ten outstanding writers, and all of us will meet on a weekly basis to each publish a 10,000 word essay by the beginning of May. I've also hand-picked a group of six stellar Write of Passage alumni to join our new ambassador program. All of them have created a proposal for a project of their choice, and we'll spend the next six months executing on each project.

Both projects are guided by a similar imperative. The growth of every community depends on the leadership of its members. I want students and alumni to build upon what they learn in the course and run with their best ideas.

‚Äã

--------

‚Äã

‚ÄãThe New American Dream‚Äã

Note: You can also read this article on my website, where you'll see a whole extra section.

Shifts in technology lead to transformative shifts in human consciousness.

The last big one happened during the 1960s, after the arrival of television when people began to see images and videos from around the world. For the first time, images from faraway lands traveled into our living rooms. As Marshall McLuhan wrote: ‚ÄúThe plight of the slum child, via the TV image, is increasingly extended to the entire population.‚Äù

The Vietnam War exemplifies its cultural impact. The protests against it were so heated because Americans saw the blood of warfare and the tears of destruction with their own eyes through the television.

Today‚Äôs children have a new way of thinking. Instead of consuming images and videos, they can produce them for a global audience. Teenagers can use GarageBand to make music or high-definition smartphone cameras to make videos. Then, they can publish their music to SoundCloud or their videos to YouTube. TikTok accelerated these trends. The algorithms on Twitter, Facebook, and Instagram are built upon the ‚Äúfriend graph,‚Äù meaning that people you friend or follow are more likely to show up in your feed. But TikTok works differently. The algorithm aims to deliver engaging videos ‚Äî no matter who made them or where they come from. Away from the spotlight of friends and family, people on TikTok don‚Äôt feel the same pressure for perfection that stops them from sharing on other social media platforms. Thus, the percentage of consumers on TikTok who also produce content is much higher than other social media platforms.

The Internet is a global talent show, and TikTok is American Idol.

Anybody anywhere can go viral. Kids know this and grow up thinking about how they can make videos for the entire world. In an age of near-infinite information, their rate of learning is limited by discipline ‚Äî not access to information. Creators don‚Äôt need teachers or help from adults. The costs of failure are low, so they know to ignore the conventional wisdom that learning should come before doing. Instead, today‚Äôs creatives learn by doing. They take action, improve their craft, and follow the incentives of the algorithm ‚Äî the same attitude that drives entrepreneurs.

There are social, technological, and theoretical reasons for the coming entrepreneurship explosion.

I‚Äôll take each in turn.

Social: Earlier this week, I had dinner with a friend from college who wants to leave his corporate job. When I asked him what he wants to do instead, he replied, ‚ÄúStart a business, of course.‚Äù His words echoed what Tyler Tringas said more explicitly: "The New American Dream is to build a profitable, sustainable, remote software business that can be run from anywhere, scales nicely, and prints money.‚Äù Starry-eyed dreamers have grown up seeing entrepreneurs like Tim Ferriss and Emily Weiss on the cover of Forbes and Time Magazine. Like them, some want to start major venture-scale businesses. Others want to bootstrap smaller franchises and software-enabled businesses with recurring revenue and comfortable margins. Those who can start profitable businesses are showered with the praise of social applause, which is amplified for everybody to see on social media.

Technological: The new creation tools are so powerful that they shorten the time it takes for people to go from novice to expert. Much of the knowledge that people used to need is now embedded in the software itself. Musicians, for example, once had to calibrate their ears to become tone literate. Now, GarageBand guarantees a pitch-perfect track and a consistent eight-count beat. Likewise, Unfold makes it easy for creators to publish beautiful Instagram stories because the app‚Äôs default settings guarantee a well-balanced image.

Almost all of these platforms have a Software-as-a-Service business model, so entrepreneurs who use them can pay little at the beginning and increase their commitment as their business grows. Here are some examples, inspired by Tyler Tringas:

  • Scalable Server Infrastructure: Heroku and Amazon Web Services
  • Social Media Platforms: Facebook, Instagram, Twitter
  • No Code Platforms: Zapier, WebFlow, Airtable, Shopify, and Squarespace
  • Basic Operations of Software Businesses: Bench Accounting, Stripe, ConvertKit, Gumroad, Zoom, GreatAssistant, and UpWork
  • Ways to Find and Validate Businesses: Traction, Lean Startup, Main Street

You no longer need to be an engineer to build a software-enabled business. I was able to teach more than 400 students in Write of Passage last year because of these tools. I run my live sessions on Zoom, integrate my APIs on Zapier, save my ideas in Evernote, host my curriculum on Teachable and my website on Squarespace, and communicate with you every Monday through ConvertKit.

Theoretical: We‚Äôre moving towards a more entrepreneurial economy, which will lead to an explosion of niche software-enabled companies. Investors like Fred Wilson and Marc Andreessen like to recommend a book called Technological Revolutions and Financial Capital. The author Carlota Perez studied the four major surges of technological development:

  • Industrial Revolution: 1771 - 1829
  • Age of Steam and Railways: 1829 - 1873
  • Age of Steel and Heavy Engineering: 1975 - 1918
  • Age of Oil, Autos, and Mass Production: 1908 - 1974
  • The Information and Communications Technology Revolution: Started in 1971 and still happening

According to Perez‚Äôs theory, these cycles unfolded in similar ways. As Jerry Neumann explained, "Each is characterized by some critical factor of production suddenly becoming very cheap, some new infrastructure being built, a laissez-faire period of wrenching innovation followed by a bubble, a post-bubble recession, a re-assertion of institutional authority, and then a period of consolidation and wide spread of the gains in productivity from using the new technology.‚Äù

Today, we are moving into the ‚ÄúDeployment Age,‚Äù characterized by widespread acceptance and application of the new paradigm of information and communications technology. For example, during the Age of Steam and Railways, technologies like the high-pressure steam engine, precision machine parts, and improved metallurgy transformed the global economy by reducing the cost of moving goods quickly and cheaply. Joint-stock companies were born, national markets were for trade and the repeal of tariffs preventing free trade led to economies of scale, and people moved away from their hometowns en masse for the first time. New businesses built upon these new foundations ‚Äî in the same way, today‚Äôs entrepreneurs are building upon the foundations of new information and communications technologies.

Just as Perez‚Äô theory predicts, the majority of companies in the coming entrepreneurship explosion will find markets with existing demand and serve them by integrating existing technologies. Crucially, entrepreneurs move away from risky exploratory projects and towards sustaining innovations with less technological volatility and fewer business failures. Companies created at the end of a technological paradigm are relatively low-risk because their products are cheap to fund and easy for customers to validate.

The combination of these social, technological, and theoretical forces have seeded the coming entrepreneurship explosion. These new companies will be built upon cheap software and founded in industries with low market risk. Thus, they‚Äôll be mostly founded by bootstrappers. And those who raise capital won‚Äôt need much of it.

As predicted by my Naked Brands thesis, people on the Internet are increasingly becoming companies. Creatives use the Internet to shrink the world and connect with like-minded people at the tails of the bell curve for obscure interests. Building an online audience is already a leading indicator of political or entrepreneurial success.

There‚Äôs a clear market opportunity for schools, investors, and coaches who focus on teaching people how to create bootstrapped software-enabled businesses. Entrepreneurs with online audiences attract better employees, acquire customers at a lower cost, and benefit from developing specific knowledge in their area of expertise.

I started Write of Passage to guide people down this path.

‚Äã

Coolest Things I Learned This Week

Writing Wisdom from a Trusted Friend

I'm preparing for the next cohort of Write of Passage, which begins on February 19th and goes on sale on February 10th. To do so, I'm reviewing my notes about writing online.

This one stuck out. I received this writing advice during a lunch with one of my favorite writers in 2018. Two years later, it holds up very well.

  1. Write at a regular cadence, don't give up.
  2. Emphasize quality growth rather than engagement. Quality is the only differentiator in the long run, try to get that nailed down before worrying about engagement.
  3. Measure the quality of a post by the number of interesting inbound emails that come from it. This metric is a good, balanced proxy for quality and reach.
  4. Don‚Äôt write on Medium. It‚Äôs generally a waste of energy. Drive people back to your website, even if it requires patience.
  5. Influence the influencers. Pick one or two big-name influencers to ‚Äúwrite for‚Äù and try to get them to share your work as often as possible.

Oh, and I'm a big fan of this quote from Nic Carter: "The cheapest leverage most people have access to is their ability to write."

‚Äã

------------

‚Äã

American Logistics

I'm going to tell a story about American geography in four maps.

1. Chicago is America‚Äôs true transportation hub. First, with freight. Commodities like iron, timber, coal, and grains all moved through Chicago by train. Now, with airplanes. It‚Äôs a hub for United and American Airlines, and for years, it was the busiest airport in the world.

‚Äã

2. Here‚Äôs a map of America‚Äôs railroads from 1918. Even then, Chicago was the center of gravity for the entire system. Today, the Chicago-based Belt Railway is the largest train switching company in America. They dispatch ~8,400 cars per day.

‚Äã

3. As a comparison, here‚Äôs a map of the U.S Highway system which is much more decentralized. Like America‚Äôs population, its center-of-gravity is shifted to the north-east, but it doesn‚Äôt run converge at a single point like rail lines do.

‚Äã

‚Äã

4. To find the center-of-gravity for air freight, you have to go South. The UPS hub is in Louisville, Kentucky. The FexEx hub is in Memphis, Tennessee. Both hubs were chosen because they‚Äôre centrally located in the U.S. and they have warm weather, so the airports rarely shut down.

‚Äã

‚Äã

5. The center of America's population is now shifting southwest, at a rate of ~12.8 inches every hour.

‚Äã

‚Äã

------------

‚Äã

‚ÄãHow God Has Changed ‚Äã

This is a fascinating quote from John O'Donohue.

Honestly, I've never heard anybody talk about God like this.

" I think that there is a wonderful danger in God that we have totally forgotten. Because one of the things humanoids like to do is they like to bring in the tamers to tame their deities down. They don‚Äôt like the idea of a wild God, because it could get very awkward, and deeply embarrassing‚Ä¶And one of the reasons that young people are leaving religion is because God has died for them, or become incredibly boring and uninteresting. And I think one of the tasks of our time, for those that are interested in God, is to make God dangerous again."

‚Äã

------------

‚Äã

‚ÄãWhere Americans Are Moving‚Äã

As a general trend, Americans are moving to low-tax states in warmer parts of the country.

‚Äã

‚Äã

------------

‚Äã

‚ÄãBusiness in Germany‚Äã

I love maps!

Here‚Äôs a map of where major companies are based in Germany.

‚Äã

Note: Sid Jha, who is one of the most talented up-and-coming writers I know. He's working on a short book about Lyndon B. Johnson. It's more than a biography. It's about the principles that govern networks, organizations, and people. You'll find all the details here.‚Äã

‚Äã

Photo of the Week

Yesterday was one of the most fun days I've ever had in New York City.

It started in Midtown Manhattan with a lecture about St. Augustine at a Church on 5th Avenue. Right after it ended, I walked onto 55th street and ran into Jason Silva who a mind-blowingly talented and inspiring YouTuber and public speaker.

Then, I spent a couple hours reading the biography of Jim Simons who is one of the most successful investors of all-time. And finally, I ended the night with a dinner and dessert at Little Mercado Spain with my favorite economist. Special, special day.

Until next week,

David Perell

item.content:encoded:
‚Äã

Hi friends,

People aren't deliberate enough about choosing what to work on.

To paraphrase the words of John O'Donohue, we are blind to the complacency that passes for ambition in modern society.

Too many of our smartest minds are working on trivial tasks and spending their time in corporations where they feel invisible. The vast majority of my friends who work for big companies say they're bored, unchallenged, and under-employed. They don't see the tangible benefits of their hard work.

Looking like you're being productive is often a better strategy than actually being productive. That's why extroverts without conviction, many of whom spend more time networking than executing, rise to the top of the corporate hierarchy.

New ideas are fragile. Since they originate in the messy madness of intuition and the fringes of society, they don't carry the crisp edges that rational critics look for. Forgetting this, we beat precious but unconventional ideas out of people before they have time to blossom.

As Peter Thiel once said:

"There's a strange phenomenon in Silicon Valley where large levels of successful founders seem to have Asperger's. You can turn that around as an indictment of society. What is it about society where if you don't have Asperger's, you‚Äôre talked out of ideas before they‚Äôre fully formed?"

Risk-averse parents and educators push children down conventional paths. Parents enroll their kids in the same schools and the same extracurriculars to help them get into the same schools and work for the same corporations. In 2007, more than half of Harvard graduates went to work in investment banking or management consulting. At Elon University, my alma mater, career advisors pushed us towards secure, but complacent careers at large corporations like three-letter media companies and the big-four accounting firms.

Too many of our top people aren't putting their differentiated skill-sets to work. They graduate from the best schools in the world only to burn their attention on standardized checklists and the high school cafeteria game theory of corporate politics. Of course, this doesn't apply to every person I know at big companies. But there are too many talented people who sleepwalk through their workday.

Entrepreneurship is one solution. Employment and independent research are two others. Unfortunately, the national rate of company formation in America has fallen, just as academia has become politicized and overly bureaucratized.

‚Äã

‚Äã

Right now, in order to do something truly innovative, you need to drop out of the system entirely or be so independent-minded that people call you a lunatic. In a time when it's easier than ever to start a company, we should encourage people to identify the important problems society ignores and find scalable solutions to them ‚Äî all while making a truck-load of profit.

Broadly, there are five buckets that talented people should start companies around: energy, education, housing, healthcare, and transportation. That‚Äôs because the western world has stagnated on all five fronts. For every sector except energy and sometimes housing, costs are rising faster than the rate of inflation.

We've made tremendous progress in other parts of the economy. Viral diseases have virtually disappeared, childbirth is safer than ever before, and we‚Äôve improved semiconductors at a remarkable rate, which is why the phones in our pockets are now so powerful. But where quality of life in America hasn't improved, you can blame the five buckets of energy, education, housing, healthcare, and transportation. And because costs in these industries are rising faster than the rate of inflation, there are huge financial opportunities.

The government sets the laws for society, so it‚Äôs a wrap for all five buckets. And there, we can do so much better too. Politics doesn't need to be the zero-sum game it is today. Because of its cut-throat nature, I know very few talented young people who want to work in government. We need more people like Dominic Cummings, a senior advisor to Boris Johnson, who is probably the most forward-thinking politician in the world today. Cummings borrows ideas from people like Bret Victor, Alan Kay, Philip Tetlock, Warren Buffett, and Charlie Munger while everybody else follows tired conventional wisdom.

Those who would work in government but choose not to say there's too much red tape and the pay isn't high enough, so they spend their time optimizing advertisements and selling copycat products instead. We don't need a 17th bottled water brand at CVS or a 28th CliffBar competitor at Walgreens. We need our best and brightest people working on important problems that wouldn't be solved otherwise.

Paradoxically, ambitious and differentiated goals are sometimes easier to achieve than mundane ones. Ambitious people attract other ambitious people. In positive-sum areas, they find ways to work together and help each other. That's why inspiring goals make it easier to hire, raise money, and meet the kinds of people who can move the world with a single phone call.

‚Äã

Coolest Things I Learned This Week

‚Äã
My Framework for Outsourcing Tasks

I hosted an Annual Review Workshop for 278 people over the weekend, and came up with this questionairre for identifying activities to outsource.

Question: What should you be outsourcing?

Goal: Spend more time on work you enjoy and capitalizing on your unique strengths.

‚Äã

What You Should Spend More Time Doing

  • What gives me energy?
  • What are my unique gifts in the world?
  • What makes me feel alive?
  • What puts me into a flow state?
  • What feels like play to me, but looks like work to others?

‚Äã
‚ÄãWhat Should You Spend Less Time Doing

  • What do I spend too much time doing?
  • What bores me?
  • What do I dread doing?
  • What do I do that other people could do?
  • Where do I procrastinate?
  • What time-consuming activities do I repeat?
  • Where do I usually make mistakes?

‚Äã
‚ÄãTasks You Can Outsource

  • Home cleaning
  • Billing
  • Event planning
  • Cooking and meal prep
  • Travel recommendations
  • Book-keeping
  • Accounting
  • Grocery shopping
  • Editing audio and video files
  • Show notes for podcasts
  • Washing and ironing clothes

‚Äã
‚ÄãPopular Outsourcing Platforms

  • House cleaning ‚Äî Handy‚Äã
  • Personal Assistant ‚Äî FancyHands‚Äã
  • Basic physical tasks ‚Äî TaskRabbit‚Äã
  • Basic digital tasks ‚Äî Upwork‚Äã
  • Transcripts ‚Äî Rev‚Äã
  • Grocery shopping ‚Äî Instacart or Amazon‚Äã

‚Äã

----------

‚Äã

‚ÄãSuperhuman Memory‚Äã

Artist Stephen Wiltshire was diagnosed with autism at age three. But he has a special talent. He can look at a city for a short amount of time, and draw the view with incredible detail ‚Äî from memory.

Joe Norman, one of my previous podcast guests, made a good observation: "Perhaps there is some important clinical relationship between ability to encode largely incompressible info and inability to generalize as it demands lossy compression."

‚Äã

‚Äã

‚Äã

‚Äã

----------

‚Äã

The Sudden Explosion of Breweries

‚Äã

‚Äã

----------

‚Äã

In Praise of Tradition

I went down a tradition rabbit hole this week, inspired by this excellent article called Tradition is Smarter Than You Are.

These quotes caught my attention:

  1. ‚ÄúTradition means giving votes to the most obscure of all classes, our ancestors. It is the democracy of the dead. Tradition refuses to submit to the small and arrogant oligarchy of those who merely happen to be walking about.‚Äù ‚Äî G.K. Chesterton
  2. ‚ÄúThe dead outnumber the living 14-to-1, and we ignore the accumulated experience of such a huge majority of mankind at our peril.‚Äù ‚Äî Niall Ferguson
  3. "The more modern type of reformer goes gaily up to [a fence] and says, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see the use of this; let us clear it away.‚Äù To which the more intelligent type of reformer will do well to answer: ‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt see the use of it, I certainly won‚Äôt let you clear it away. Go away and think. Then, when you can come back and tell me that you do see the use of it, I may allow you to destroy it." ‚Äî G.K. Chesterton, The Thing (1929).

Also... if you want to hear about the best links I find every week, you should subscribe to my Friday Finds newsletter.

‚Äã

----------

‚Äã

I Love These Photos

‚Äã

‚Äã

Photo of the Week

I spent last week golfing at Streamsong in Florida.

After shooting four straight rounds in the mid-70s, I'm ready to get back to work, but I already miss golfing. The beauty, the strategy, the technique. All of it.

Part of me wishes I could take a year off, team up with a golf coach, practice full-time, and try to play professionally. It's the dream I'm quietly avoiding. Rationally, I'm not nearly good enough to actually make it on tour.

But who cares?

I have such a passionate love for the game that my dream of going pro will never fade. 14-year-old David wants me to give up everything and just play golf.

Here's the compromise. In the future, I'll try to qualify for the U.S. Open and the U.S. Amateur tournaments, when I can commit the time and energy. But until then, I'll be in your inbox every single Monday.

Until next week,

David Perell

‚Äã

‚Äã

First, I'm working on a long-form essay about the downsides of excessive news consumption. It's 15,000 words, or the rough equivalent of 40 single-spaced pages. I'm looking for five editors to review a draft. If you'd like to provide feedback, please let me know by responding to this email.

Second, if you know a professional writing editor or work as one yourself, this opportunity is for you.

You'll work with a participant of the Write of Passage Fellowship to write an outstanding 15,000 word essay. If you're interested, please respond to this email with a writing sample and a description of why you're the right person to hire. Here's what I'm looking for:

  • Willingness to question assumptions, theories and facts.
  • Visualize the end product while focusing on and remembering details.
  • Recognize what's missing in an essay and provide concrete solutions for improvement.

I have high standards but you'll be rewarded with fair pay and interesting work.
